author: Staff Reporter
text:
Some of the students found language paper tricky

tense moments:A visually challenged student checking her hall ticket before stepping into the examination hall at Mogappair East in Chennai.- Photo: M. Vedhan.

More than eight lakh students appeared for the language paper on day one of the Plus Two State Board public examinations on Friday.

Official sources said 8.39 lakh students, including 42,347 private candidates, took the language paper at 6,550 centres across Tamil Nadu.

In Chennai, some of the students found the examination tricky. “The one and four mark questions were confusing. I was confident of scoring full marks earlier, but now I am doubtful,” said S. Keerthana of DAV Matriculation Higher Secondary School, Gill Nagar.

Tense parents were found waiting outside examination centres.

“I took a day’s leave from work. My daughter was worried last night about her French exam and I hope she fares well,” said S. Ramanathan, whose daughter is studying at a school in Ashok Nagar.

“Some parts of the paper were difficult as the questions were culled deep from the syllabus. Students might not have been prepared. We will be more careful with our homework next year and rise up to the expectations,” said M Jainulabudeen, a Tamil teacher at the Government Girls Higher Secondary School, Ashok Nagar.

“I did today’s paper well. I feel it is a good start for the entire examination,” said an excited S.Mahadir, student of Asan Memorial school.
title: Plus Two examinations begin on a tough note
